definitions.definition: either side of the face below the eyes
definitions.labels: (informal)(formal)(British English)(British English)(disapproving)(both informal, often disapproving)(informal, disapproving)

examples.text: **chubby/rosy/pink cheeks**
He kissed her on both cheeks.
Couples were dancing **cheek to cheek**.
Colour flooded to her cheeks when she realized she was being watched.
He felt his cheeks burning with shame.
I kissed her on both cheeks and got on the train.
He rested his cheek on her shoulder.
Her cheeks were wet with tears.
His red-rimmed eyes and sunken cheeks betrayed his lack of sleep.
She dabbed at her cheeks with a handkerchief.
I gave him a peck on the cheek and said goodbye.
She gave him a sharp slap across his cheek.
He had a healthy bloom in his cheeks.
She laid her cheek against his.
She proffered her cheek to kiss.
He smiled at me and the colour rose to my cheeks.

phrases: bring the colour/​color (back) to somebody’s cheeks
the colour/​color rises to your cheeks

definitions.definition: having the type of cheeks mentioned

examples.text: chubby-cheeked/rosy-cheeked/hollow-cheeked

definitions.definition: talk or behaviour that people think is annoying, rude or not showing enough respect

examples.text: What a cheek!
He **had the cheek** to ask his ex-girlfriend to babysit for them.
I think they've **got a cheek** making you pay to park the car.
Of all the damned cheek! Make your own coffee!
What struck him most was the colossal cheek of it all.
It's an awful cheek, the way he keeps asking you to lend him money.
She asked you for money? Of all the cheek!
He's got a cheek, making you wait outside his office.
The guests, packed cheek by jowl, parted as he entered.

definitions.definition: to make a deliberate decision to remain calm and not to act in an aggressive way when somebody has hurt you or made you angry
if you say something with your tongue in your cheek, you are not being serious and mean it as a joke

wordOrigin: Old English cē(a)ce, cēoce ‘cheek, jaw’, of West Germanic origin; related to Dutch kaak.
